section.title: Present simple and continuous
section.sectiontitle: We use the Present simple for repeated actions or habits and something we see as permanent.
section.sectiontitle2: We also use the Present simple for a state that doesn't change.

section.title: Present simple and continuous
section.sectiontitle: We use the Present continuous for an action in progress at the moment of speaking or a temporary situation (something happening 'around now').
section.text1: an action in progress at the moment of speaking
section.text2a: I'm trying to find a new apartment.
section.sectiontitle2: We also use the Present continuous for a changing situation.
section.text4a: The cost of petrol is going up.

section.title: Present simple and continuous
section.sectiontitle: In continuous tenses, we almost never use 'state' verbs (things which stay the same). These include verbs connected with emotions and understanding.
section.text1: verbs of emotion: hate, like, love, want
section.text2: verbs of understanding: believe, know, prefer, understand
section.sectiontitle2: Other 'state' verbs are verbs connected with possession, unchanging qualities, or the senses.
section.text3: verbs of possession or unchanging qualities: belong, own, cost, weigh
section.text4: verbs of the senses hear, smell, sound, taste
